title: Improved Self-Organizing Map Clustering of Power Transformer Dissolved Gas Analysis Using Inputs Pre-Processing
abstract: Ability to organize data spatially while conserving the topological relation between data features makes the Self Organizing Map (SOM) a very useful tool for analysis and visualization of high dimensional data such as a power transformer's Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA). Past SOM application required large historical data for its training and has limited fault detection sensitivity. In this paper, the effects of input features and data normalization are studied to enhance SOM's clustering. SOM is trained using DGA results extracted from actual faulted transformers. Combination of input features and data normalization methods are tested on SOM before the best SOM is identified. Validation is conducted using several datasets i.e. the IEC Technical Committee 10 database. Compared with past SOM applications, the proposed SOM required lesser training data, improved SOM's sensitivity in incipient fault detection and has good diagnosis accuracy. The proposed SOM is also compared with other AI-based DGA interpretation method i.e. Support Vector Machine (SVM) for benchmarking.
full_text:
Received March 8, 2020, accepted March 30, 2020, date of publication April 8, 2020, date of current version April 29, 2020.
Digital Object Identifier 10.1 109/ACCESS.2020.2986726
Improved Self-Organizing Map Clustering of
Power Transformer Dissolved Gas Analysis
Using Inputs Pre-Processing
SYAHIDUDDIN MISBAHULMUNIR
1, VIGNA K. RAMACHANDARAMURTHY1,
AND YASMIN H. MD. THAYOOB2
1Institute of Power Engineering, Department of Electrical Power Engineering, College of Engineering, UNITEN, Kajang 43000, Malaysia
2Asset Management Department, Tenaga Nasional Berhad (TNB), Petaling Jaya 46200, Malaysia
Corresponding author: Syahiduddin Misbahulmunir (syahiduddin.misbahulmunir@gmail.com)
This work was supported in part by the Institute of Power Engineering, Department of Electrical Power Engineering, College of
Engineering, UNITEN.
ABSTRACT Ability to organize data spatially while conserving the topological relation between data
features makes the Self Organizing Map (SOM) a very useful tool for analysis and visualization of high
dimensional data such as a power transformer’s Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA). Past SOM application
required large historical data for its training and has limited fault detection sensitivity. In this paper, the effects
of input features and data normalization are studied to enhance SOM’s clustering. SOM is trained using DGA
results extracted from actual faulted transformers. Combination of input features and data normalization
methods are tested on SOM before the best SOM is identiﬁed. Validation is conducted using several datasets
i.e. the IEC Technical Committee 10 database. Compared with past SOM applications, the proposed SOM
required lesser training data, improved SOM’s sensitivity in incipient fault detection and has good diagnosis
accuracy. The proposed SOM is also compared with other AI-based DGA interpretation method i.e. Support
Vector Machine (SVM) for benchmarking.
INDEX TERMS Dissolved gas analysis, fault detection, power transformer, self-organizing map, data
pre-processing.
I. INTRODUCTION
Power transformers must always be kept healthy and opera-
tional to maintain a reliable and efﬁcient electrical network.
Failure of power transformers may cause substantial damage,
including loss of human life.
The Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA) is extensively used to
monitor and diagnose incipient faults in power transformers.
Gases dissolved in the insulating oil are extracted, identiﬁed,
and measured, before interpretation of the DGA results are
made. These gases are by-products of the oil when exposed
to thermal and electrical energy, especially those caused by
faults. The amount and type of these gases are dependent on
the amount of energy the oil is exposed to [1].
Due to the complex and stoichiometric nature of the oil
degradation process [1], DGA interpretation via gas ratio
approach such as proposed by the IEC 60599 may arrive
to the state of ‘no interpretation’ or inaccurate diagnosis.
Insufﬁcient ratio-combinations or ‘code-absence’ may also
The associate editor coordinating the review of this manuscript and
approving it for publication was Ugur Guvenc
.
cause the interpretation of DGA to become invalid [2]–[4].
These are the main factors that initiated the use of Artiﬁcial
Intelligence (AI) in DGA interpretation. Other factors include
high dependency on an expert’s opinion and inability of
standard methods to adapt to various designs and materials of
power transformers. Among the categories of AI used in DGA
interpretation are i.e. neural networks [5]–[9], fuzzy logic or
fuzzy inference system [10]–[12], clustering or classiﬁcation
algorithm [13]–[18], and hybrid [19]–[22].
The Self-Organizing Map (SOM) is among the earliest
AI used for DGA interpretation [23]. Moderate computation
difﬁculty in developing SOM enables faster learning process.
SOM is globally ordered and does not have the issue of local
minimum [24]. SOM is also considered robust to arbitrary
data [2].
Past applications of SOM required a large number of
DGA results for its training (755 in [25], 963 in [26] and
390 in [27]). Validation of SOM in [25] is done through com-
parison with diagnosis produced by the conventional method.
In [26], the focus of research is on ageing and not on incipient
fault detection, while in [27] the validation of SOM is not
71798 This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License. For more information, see https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/VOLUME 8, 2020
S. Misbahulmuniret al.: Improved SOM Clustering of Power Transformer DGA Using Inputs Pre-Processing
TABLE 1. DGA interpretation table in IEC 60599.
clearly stated. Training and testing data in these researches
comprised of DGA results localized to the research while
fault diagnosis is limited to detecting only 3 general fault
types i.e. Thermal Fault (T), Electrical Discharge (D) and
Partial Discharge (PD).
In more recent applications, SOM is combined with
other artiﬁcial intelligence methods such as Support Vector
Machine [28], Bayes Classiﬁer [27] and Principal Compo-
nent Analysis [29]. Paper [28] presented a relative diagnosis
of oil and paper condition, paper [27] reported the detection
of electrical discharge, thermal fault and partial discharge
detection, and paper [29] focused on the detection of partial
discharge sources. Despite SOM showing good potential in
various power transformer diagnosis, current SOM still lacks
the detection of fault severity in its DGA interpretation.
In this paper, SOM is trained using various combinations
of input features and normalization methods. The training and
testing datasets are collected from [30]. Validation is also
done using actual fault cases from the IEC TC10 database.
Comparison with past SOM applications and other AI-based
DGA interpretation method is also presented and the pro-
posed method showed good diagnosis accuracy.
The ﬁrst section brieﬂy explained how DGA is performed
and listed issues concerning its interpretation. Some of the
present AI-based DGA interpretation methods are also high-
lighted. The second section gives an overview of DGA inter-
pretation method based on the IEC 60599 standard. The third
and fourth section describes SOM’s algorithm and its diagno-
sis process respectively. The section that follows presents the
result of SOM’s interpretation and its validation. Finally, con-
clusion and future works are deliberated in the last section.
II. DGA INTERPRETATION METHOD BASED
ON THE IEC 60599
Events such as overloading, switching and faults, release ther-
mal energy inside the power transformer, causing the insulat-
ing oil to degrade. The oil degradation process produced gases
i.e. Hydrogen (H2), Methane (CH4), Ethane (C2H6), Ethy-
lene (C2H4), Acetylene (C2H2) and Carbon Monoxide (CO).
There are other gases produced due to the degradation,
however the above mentioned are the key gases monitored
in DGA. The type and amount of these dissolved gases,
according to [1], correlate with six classes of faults that can
be categorized visually:
• Partial discharges (PD)
• Discharges of low energy (D1)
• Discharges of high energy (D2)
• Thermal faults of temperatures below 300 ◦C (T1)
• Thermal faults of temperatures 300 ◦C to 700 ◦C (T2)
• Thermal faults of temperatures above 700 ◦C (T3)
Identiﬁcation of fault is done using ratio calculation,
as shown in Table 1. Combination of calculated gas ratios
determines the type of fault experienced by the transformer.
This table is used when at least one of the gases exceeds its
typical gassing rates under normal operation. The same rule
is applied when using the proposed SOM for fault diagnosis.
A. DUVAL, ROGERS AND DOERNENBURG RATIO
Duval Ratio uses the calculation of triangular coordinate
to categorize the type of fault [1]. Duval Pentagon was
then introduced to complement the Duval Ratio [31]. The
Duval Pentagon is considered the latest in its method. How-
ever, its use is to complement the Duval Ratio and not to
replace it. The Rogers Ratio and Doernenberg Ratio use a
similar approach to the IEC Ratio, but differs in the DGA
interpretation table used [32]. In this paper, a combined ratio
is proposed as shown in Table 2. These ratios will be studied
as the input features to SOM.
B. IEC TC10 DATABASE
IEC TC 10 database [33] is the reference used in the develop-
ment and revision of the IEC 60599 standard. The database
consists of DGA results observed in thousands of power
transformers, produced by different manufacturers, and oper-
ating in various individual network around the world. Due to
its large and multi-manufacturer collection, this database is
commonly accepted as the universal database and is selected
to validate the accuracy of the proposed SOM in this paper.
III. THE SELF-ORGANIZING MAP (SOM) AND ITS
APPLICATION FOR DGA INTERPRETATION
Inspired by the retina-cortex mapping in the human eyes, the
network diagram of SOM is illustrated in Figure 1. SOM is
a 2-layer, non-supervised neural network that organizes its
VOLUME 8, 2020 71799
S. Misbahulmuniret al.: Improved SOM Clustering of Power Transformer DGA Using Inputs Pre-Processing
TABLE 2. Rogers, Duval and combined ratio.
FIGURE 1. Structure diagram and key definition.
output based on the nature of its input data. Inputs to SOM
are vectors connected to all nodes on the output plane. The
output layer consists of weighted nodes arranged on a 2D
map. The dimension or weight of each output node matches
the dimension of the input vector. SOM’s learning process
goes through the following steps [24]:
1) The weight of the nodes on the output plane are initial-
ized using random real values
2) One input is selected randomly from the training
database
3) The Euclidean distance is calculated between the
selected input vector and each of the node’s weight on
the output map, using equation (1)
4) The node with the lowest Euclidean distance to the
input is selected as the BMU
5) The neighbourhood function of the BMU is calculated
using equation (2)
6) The weight of the nodes within the neighbourhood of
the BMU, is updated using equation (3)
7) The process is repeated until convergence
Euclidean distance calculation between input vector and
node’s weight, Dist:
Dist =
√
∑i=n
i=0 (Vi −Ui)2 (1)
where Vi is the input vector; Ui is the node’s weight.
Neighbourhood function of the BMU, Wbi(t):
Wbi(t) =α(t)e
sd(b,i)
2δ2(t) (2)
where t is the step or iteration count; b is the index of the Best
Matching Unit (BMU); α(t) is the learning rate; δ(t) is the
neighbourhood radius; sd(b,i) is the square distance between
node b (the BMU) and i on the output plane. Both α(t) and
δ(t) are decreasing scalar functions to ensure convergence of
the SOM.
Weight update function for nodes on the output plane at
iteration t:
Ui(t) =Ui +Wbi (t)[Vi −Ui] (3)
In short, on the output plane, the nodes’ weights will be
updated based on the inputs vector, resulting in nodes with
high similarity to be ‘mapped’ closer to each other while
nodes with low similarity will be mapped further from each
other. The process is iterated until the SOM converges, pro-
ducing a feature map, where nodes with high similarities
are clustered. Using the SOM feature map, diagnosis of trans-
former condition using DGA result can be done by plotting
the DGA result with the unknown transformer condition
onto the feature map. The location of the plot or the cluster
where the DGA result is mapped represents the incipient fault
of the power transformer.
IV. DIAGNOSIS PROCESS
A. TRAINING THE SOM
In this paper, the diagnosis process is divided into two stages.
First, the training of the SOM (refer Figure 2) and second, the
validation (testing) of the developed SOM feature map (refer
the following section for details).
Prior to creating the SOM, a review is conducted on various
AI-based DGA interpretation methods. All input features and
normalization methods from these papers are identiﬁed and
summarized in Table 3 and Table 4. The result shows that
input features used in 33 researches are mainly ratios i.e. IEC
ratio, Duval ratio, Doernenberg ratio and the Rogers ratio,
while the two most frequently used normalization methods
are the range and ratio normalization.
Input features and normalization methods identiﬁed from
these researches are combined and used as SOM’s input.
Other input features and normalization methods are also
71800 VOLUME 8, 2020
S. Misbahulmuniret al.: Improved SOM Clustering of Power Transformer DGA Using Inputs Pre-Processing
FIGURE 2. Development of SOM feature map.
TABLE 3. Input features identified from other AI-based DGA interpretation methods.
TABLE 4. Normalization method identified from other AI-based DGA
interpretation methods.
added to increase the possibility of ﬁnding the best combina-
tion of input features and normalization methods for SOM.
Table 5 and Table 6 list the combination of normalization
methods and input features experimented in this research.
A total of 540 DGA results with known faults are collected
from [30]. These DGA results consisted of six fault types i.e.
D1 (78 cases), D2 (147 cases), PD (57 cases), T1 (101 cases),
T2 (68 cases) and T3 (89 cases).
To determine the best combination of input features and
normalization methods, three criteria are evaluated i.e. the
topological error [34], cluster existence and component plane.
Topological error measures the ratio of DGA data vectors,
where its ﬁrst and second BMUs are not neighbouring units,
to the total of DGA vectors plotted on the output plane.
Hence, low topological error means the topology of the input
data is preserved.
VOLUME 8, 2020 71801
S. Misbahulmuniret al.: Improved SOM Clustering of Power Transformer DGA Using Inputs Pre-Processing
TABLE 5. Normalization methods used in this research.
TABLE 6. Combination of input features and normalization methods.
Cluster existence including clear separation between clus-
ters demonstrate the feature map’s capability to segregate the
DGA results according to its fault.
Each SOM has a component plane that shows the distri-
bution and density of its inputs [34]. These inputs are gas
concentrations. According to [32], the key gases for each type
of fault are; partial discharge (H2, CH4), thermal fault involv-
ing oil (C2H4, C2H6, CH4), and electrical discharge fault
(H2, C2H2). Thus, the best combination of input features
and normalization method is also identiﬁed by observing
the component plane that has the distribution and density of
gases matching the type and severity of the fault as described
in [32].
In this research, the MATLAB software and SOM Tool-
box [34] are used in the simulations of SOM. According to
the creator of SOM, the use of such toolbox is recommended
to ensure correct implementation of SOM [34].
B. VALIDATING THE SOM FEATURE MAP
Theoretically, higher number of training datasets will
improve SOM’s diagnosis accuracy. However, these datasets
need to be checked for inconsistencies e.g. two or more
datasets having almost the same value and composition of
gases but with different fault types. In actual, this can happen
because some of these gases may have been released prior to
the oil sampling process. Different additives in insulating oil
may also cause different gassing rates. These datasets are con-
sidered as outliers and are removed during SOM’s training.
TABLE 7. SOM simulation results.
To minimize the effect of outliers, the approach of ﬁnding
the best training-test ratio (achieving best diagnosis accuracy)
is applied. First, each fault type from [30] is divided into
ﬁve almost equally sized portions. Then, a portion from each
fault type is combined to make a section. Next, these sections
are then accumulated to produce several training-test ratios
of 20:80, 40:60, 60:40 and 80:20. Finally, the SOM is sim-
ulated across these training-test ratios. The best training-test
ratio is selected when the best diagnosis accuracy is achieved.
Comparison is also done between the proposed SOM
and the Support Vector Machine (SVM). Both AI-based

FIGURE 4. Comparison of component planes between combination F28 and F30.
methods are simulated using the same training data. It is
worth to mention that this is also a comparison between an
unsupervised learning (the proposed SOM) and supervised
learning (SVM).
To further validate the feature map, DGA results with
known faults from the IEC TC10 database [33] are mapped
directly on the SOM feature map developed earlier. These
data are not part of the training data and is totally foreign

to the feature map. The feature map is validated if the known
fault (of the test data) matches the fault cluster where the test
data are mapped.
V. ANALYSIS OF RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
A. BEST COMBINATION OF INPUT FEATURES,
NORMALIZATION METHODS AND COMPARISON WITH
PAST SOM APPLICATION
To determine the best combination of input features and
normalization method, three criteria are evaluated i.e. the
topological error [34], cluster existence, and component
plane.
Table 7 listed the top ten combinations of input features
and normalization method with the lowest topological error.
Past SOM application [25], [27] and the proposed SOM are
represented by combination F1 and F30 respectively. Both
SOMs were trained using the same set of data [30] and the
topological error recorded are 0.006 and 0.004 respectively.
The proposed SOM has lesser topological error than past
SOM application. Fault clusters can be seen clearly compared
71804 VOLUME 8, 2020
S. Misbahulmuniret al.: Improved SOM Clustering of Power Transformer DGA Using Inputs Pre-Processing
TABLE 9. Comparison of past SOM versus proposed SOM.
FIGURE 6. Proposed SOM mapped with DGA results from the IEC TC10 database (validation phase). Left: 22 DGA
results from power transformer with communicating OLTC. Right: 36 DGA results from power transformer with
non-communicating OLTC. Green squares indicate correct mapping, red means otherwise. (Key: a= T3, b= T2, c= T1,
d = PD, e= D1, f= D2).
to past SOM application where the cluster is non-existent. Six
clearly visible clusters labelled as D1, D2, PD, T1, T2, and
T3 are shown on the proposed SOM. Previous SOM applica-
tions have no clear cluster and have no separation between
them. Combination F5 and F6 also share the same result
where the cluster is non-existent. Summary of comparisons
are listed in Table 9 and shown in Figure 3.
Combination F28 has lower topological error than the F30.
Both component planes have the type and position of gases
matching the key gas criteria [32]. However, the distribution
of gases on F30 is better than the F28 due to the much clearer
gradient observed. Component planes from F28 and F30 are
compared in Figure 4.
For SOM simulated using combination F30, the severity
of fault can be seen increases as the area moves from middle
right to the top left for electrical discharge faults, and from
bottom right to middle left for thermal faults. The partial
discharge cluster has no severity levels and remains in the
zone where H2 and CH4 is present. Refer Figure 5.
In short, combination F30 produced a SOM which has low
topological error and clear fault clusters. Most importantly,
the type, distribution and density of gases observed on its

component plane matches the key gas criteria and has a good
gradient.
B. BEST TRAINING-TEST RATIO
The proposed SOM is simulated using several training-
test ratios. The resulting diagnosis accuracy is recorded
in Table 8. The SOM is trained and tested using the train-test
ratios of 20:80, 40:60, 60:40 and 80:20. The result shows
that the best diagnosis accuracy is achieved at train-test ratio
of 60:40. Thus, the SOM simulated at this stage is selected
as the SOM feature map. Further addition of the training data
renders the diagnosis accuracy quite steeply.
C. COMPARISON WITH OTHER AI-BASED DGA
INTERPRETATION METHOD
For comparison purpose, another AI-based DGA interpre-
tation method i.e. the Support Vector Machine is trained
and tested using the same data and across the same
71808 VOLUME 8, 2020
S. Misbahulmuniret al.: Improved SOM Clustering of Power Transformer DGA Using Inputs Pre-Processing
train-test ratios. The SVM uses the Radial Basis Function
kernel (Tensor Flow settings of C=10, Gamma scale setting)
and the result is compared with the proposed SOM in Table 8.
The best diagnosis accuracy for SVM is achieved at the
train-test ratio of 60:40. Further addition of the training data
does not improve the diagnosis accuracy. Comparatively, this
shows that the SOM has acquired enough training using 60%
of the training data and further addition is not required.
D. VALIDATION OF THE PROPOSED SOM USING IEC
TC10 AND PUBLISHED DATABASE
In the IEC TC10 database, DGA results are divided into
six main categories i.e. reactor, instrument transformers,
bushing, cable, power transformers with communicating
on-load tap changer (OLTC), and power transformers with
non-communicating OLTC. In this research, the focus is on
power transformers.
To validate the proposed SOM, DGA results with known
faults from the IEC TC10 database are plotted onto the map.
The plotted map is shown in Figure 6 and the details of the
validation are listed in Table 10. The diagnosis accuracy of the
proposed SOM on DGA extracted from transformers without
communicating OLTC and with communicating OLTC are
77.8% and 72.7% respectively.
Looking at Figure 6 and Table 10, it is worth mentioning
that almost all the errors recorded are neighbouring errors e.g.
a D1 fault clustered within D2 zones whilst being near to the
border of D1-D2. In this research, this is recorded as an error
although it is a severity error, not a fault type error. Obtaining
deﬁnitive border remains an issue and will be considered in
future research. If the results were evaluated based on the
main types of fault (thermal, discharge of electrical, and par-
tial discharge), the diagnosis accuracy of the proposed SOM
on DGA extracted from transformers without communicating
OLTC and with communicating OLTC areto 100% and 95.5%
respectively.
In the spirit of research, the universality of the proposed
SOM is also tested against DGA results from other types of
equipment in the IEC TC10 database i.e. reactor, instrument
transformer, bushing, and cable. A total of 51 DGA results are
available and the average diagnosis accuracy for fault severity
detection and fault type identiﬁcation are 84.3% and 96.1%.
This shows that the proposed SOM is capable of diagnosing
faults even in equipment other than the power transformer.
All these results are summarized in Table 10.
VI. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORKS
In this research, the application of SOM to interpret DGA
results is improved through the combination of input features
and normalization method. SOM using a combination of nor-
malized gas ratios as inputs produced accurate fault clusters
and clearer boundaries compared to past SOM which uses
individual gases as inputs.
Best combination of input features and normalization
method is selected from SOM that produced low topological
error, identiﬁable cluster with separation, and component
planes with distribution and density of gases that match the
key gas criteria.
Compared with previous applications of SOM, the pro-
posed SOM uses lesser data and has improved fault sensitiv-
ity. The component planes of the proposed SOM provided a
good means of indicating fault severity. The proposed SOM
also has clear clusters and improved cluster separation that
facilitate fault identiﬁcation.
The diagnosis accuracy of the proposed SOM is also com-
pared with other AI-based DGA interpretation method i.e.
SVM. It is worth mentioning that the proposed SOM is an
unsupervised learning method while the SVM is a supervised
learning method. Comparatively, 60% of the training data is
enough to train the SOM.
The feature map is validated using DGA results extracted
from the IEC TC10 database. Diagnosis accuracy average for
DGA results for transformers without communicating OLTC
and with communicating OLTC are 77.8% and 72.7% respec-
tively. The proposed SOM is also tested with DGA results
from other equipment i.e. reactor, instrument transformer,
bushing, and cable. High diagnosis accuracy average shows
that the proposed SOM is capable of diagnosing faults even
in equipment other than the power transformer.
The SOM provides simplicity and practicality of assess-
ment by having a visual map, easily understood by non-
experts. From the component planes, the proposed SOM
has shown its capability of not only detecting incipi-
ent faults, but also showing gradients of fault severity.
This is very useful for future works involving condition
monitoring.
In a nutshell, the proposed SOM has been improved almost
entirely using the right combination of input features and
normalization method.
For future works, this SOM will be studied to indicate fault
severity and possibly becoming a universal tool for detecting
incipient faults for all equipment using hydrocarbon-based
insulating oil. The issue of determining the exact border
between clusters remains to be studied.
ACKNOWLEDGMENT

P. Abd Karim, Dr. Fakhrul Zaman Rokhani, and Indra M. Zin

SYAHIDUDDIN MISBAHULMUNIR received
the M.Eng. degree in electrical engineering from
Universiti Tenaga Nasional, Malaysia, in 2009,
where he is currently pursuing the Ph.D. degree in
electrical engineering. From 2002 to 2015, he was
an Electrical Engineer with Tenaga Nasional
Berhad and PETRONAS, Malaysia. Since 2015,
he has been a Lecturer with the Depart-
ment of Engineering, Universiti Putra Malaysia.
His research area is in the application of artiﬁcial
intelligence on fault diagnosis of high-voltage power transformers. Since
2002, he has been a member of the Board of Engineers, Malaysia. He has
been a member of the Institute of Engineers, Malaysia, since 2012.
71810 VOLUME 8, 2020
S. Misbahulmuniret al.: Improved SOM Clustering of Power Transformer DGA Using Inputs Pre-Processing
VIGNA K. RAMACHANDARAMURTHY rec-
eived the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineer-
ing from The University of Manchester Institute
of Science and Technology, Manchester, U.K.,
in 2001. He is currently a Professor and the Head
of the Institute of Power Engineering, Universiti
Tenaga Nasional, Malaysia. He also leads several
research and consultancy projects. He has authored
or coauthored several international IEEE journals
in conferences. His main research interests are
power system studies, power system protection, power quality, renewable
energy integration, and the grid impact of distributed generation.
YASMIN H. MD. THAYOOBreceived the B.Sc.
degree in electrical engineering from the Univer-
sity of Miami, USA, in 1987, the M.Sc. degree in
electronics from the University of Southampton,
U.K., in 1990, and the Ph.D. degree in electri-
cal engineering from Universiti Tenaga Nasional,
in 2008. She is currently a Senior Engineer
with the Asset Management Department, Tenaga
Nasional Berhad (TNB), an electrical utility com-
pany of Malaysia. She has authored or coauthored
several international IEEE journals in conferences. Her research interests
include condition monitoring and the diagnosis of high-voltage equipment,
digital signal processing, pattern classiﬁcation and recognition, artiﬁcial
neural networks, and intelligent systems.
